One of the best films of 2023 and fully deserving of its nomination for Best Picture and its wins for Best International and Best Sound in particular. No movie has made me feel so abhorred for its subjects for their apathy and disregard for human life. Though you never see their victims, they were real people, just like you and I, and the choice of the film makers to never portray them in the film is a reflection of the‚Ä¶

Chilling, suffocating, and brutally restrained ‚Äî The Zone of Interest is a masterclass in showing horror without showing it. Glazer‚Äôs detached, almost clinical approach makes the evil feel even more monstrous, embedding it into the everyday rhythms of a "normal" life. The sound design does half the heavy lifting, and it‚Äôs terrifying in ways that visuals could never achieve. Christian Friedel and Sandra H√ºller are hauntingly ordinary, which is exactly the point. It‚Äôs not an easy watch, but it‚Äôs essential, and it lingers long after the credits roll like a sickness you can‚Äôt shake.

This was discussed on the most recent episode of the Video Archives podcast, which got me intrigued to see this. I‚Äôve never seen any adaptation of this material before. This is the 1936 version, starring Randolph Scott as Hawkeye.This film has everything: fully realized characters, who I was totally invested in, several competing factions, all with their reasons, a great depiction (both positively and negatively) of military codes of honor and duty and lots and lots of action.

If I didn't fell in love with the Mann version years ago, this could be my favourite "the last of the mohicans" picture. They made a bunch of them since the silent era. This one, class 1936, holds the test of time, except for the deaths by firearm that are kind of silly, but having say that what a gorgeous film that Seitz pull out of this ever green story. Randalph Scott as Hawkeye gives han solo vibes to his‚Ä¶
Watched due to the Video Archives Podcast.

Although not the first on-screen adaptation of James Fenimore Cooper's iconic 1826 novel, its clear that many of the future tellings of this tale owe a great deal to this George B. Seitz work, which features a younger Randolph Scott as the central Hawkeye, a scout who is tasked with escorting two daughters of Colonel Monroe safely through the brutal French and Native American War.A leaner, more adventurous take on the story than many of the other cinematic adaptions,‚Ä¶

You don't see many films set during the Boshin War, so was pretty excited to see this especially when it was advertised back in November 2024. The plot was the stock standard underdogs trying to defend against all odds, but the action was pretty solid. The campiness made the film fairly endearing, when you have a samurai ride up wearing a fedora and smoking a cigarette, you've got my attention. It's on Netflix at the moment, so solid action film for a quiet night but don't expect anything special.
